I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  To support its efforts in poverty reduction and coastal fisheries resource management, 
the Government of Indonesia (the Government) has requested the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) for technical  assistance  (TA)  to  prepare  the  Integrated  Coastal  Fisheries  Resource 
Management (ICFRM) Project. The TA Fact-Finding Mission visited Indonesia in April 2004 and 
discussed  the  project  concept  with  representatives  of  Government  agencies,  regional 
governments, nongovernment organizations (NGOs) and coastal communities. The Mission 
reached understandings with the Government on the objectives, scope and components, cost 
estimates  and  financing  plan,  implementation  arrangements,  and  terms  of  reference  for 
consultants for the TA. The TA is included in ADB’s 2004 country assistance program for 
Indonesia.1 The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Indonesia is the world’s largest archipelagic nation. Its 81,000-kilomenter (km) coastline, 
the second longest in the world, is a critical lifeline that anchors the country’s social, economic, 
and environmental development. The coastal zone is a highly productive ecosystem that serves 
as an important base for the country’s growth. Whether measured in economic or environmental 
terms, or by the more fundamental standard of output of consumable food protein, Indonesia’s 
coastal area contributes significantly to its overall productivity. The coastal zone provides food 
and livelihood to the country’s coastal communities and hosts numerous economic activities,  
including  capture  fisheries  and  aquaculture,  which  supply  the  bulk  of  the  country’s  fish 
requirements. The coastal waters contribute over 55% of the national fish harvest and food 
fish provide about 67% of the animal protein consumed by the population. The fisheries sector 
contributed 2.3% of the gross domestic product (GDP) in 2002. In addition, some of the richest 
areas of biodiversity occur in the coastal zone of the country and include coral reefs, mangrove 
swamps, seagrass beds, lagoons, and estuaries. 
 
3.  However, the Indonesian marine and fisheries sector is beset with a number of problems 
that need to be addressed to ensure its sustainable development and management. Foremost 
among  these  are  the  two  critical  and  interrelated  issues  of  pervasive  poverty  in  coastal 
communities  and  resource  degradation  due  to  habitat  degradation,  overfishing,  pollution, 
erosion,  and  siltation.  The  sector  continues  to  suffer  from  policy,  legal,  and  institutional 
constraints affecting marine and fisheries resource management.  
 
4.  To address the problems of resources management and poverty in the coastal areas, in 
1999 the Government created the Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries (MMAF), to be the 
lead agency in coastal resource management. MMAF prepared the Strategic Plan (2005-2009) 
for  sustainable  management  and  use  of  coastal  and  marine  ecosystems  and  fisheries 
resources. The plan emphasizes the following strategies: (i) development and management of 
the coastal and fisheries sector to contribute to national economy and food security, (ii) coastal 
community empowerment and participation in the ICFRM process, (iii) provision of alternative 
livelihood  and  basic  services  to  increase  income  and  improve  living  conditions  of  coastal 
communities, (iv) pollution and erosion control, and (v) development of an ICFRM program and 
capacity building on sustainable management of marine and fisheries resource. The legal basis 
for coastal fisheries resource management is articulated in several laws, the most important of 
which are the Law No.9/1985 on Fisheries, Law No. 5/1990, Conservation of Living Natural 
Resources and the Environment, Law No. 22/1999 on Regional Governance and Law No.

2  
25/1999 on Financial Balance between Central and Regional Governments, as well as relevant 
ministerial decrees of MMAF. However, no single law or regulation officially recognizes the 
ICFRM Project as a management approach.  
 
5.  Since the 1990s, various measures and programs were adopted in 80 coastal districts all 
over  the  country  to  promote  the  ICFRM  Project.  However,  these  measures  emphasized 
research, resource evaluation and planning, and pilot field implementation rather than resource 
management. Their impacts on coastal resources management have been limited due to lack of 
an integrated approach and broad-based participation by stakeholders.  
 
6.  ADB has actively supported the Government’s efforts in marine and coastal resource 
management and fisheries development through loans and TAs. In the last 10 years, MMAF has 
implemented five ADB marine and coastal fisheries resource management projects.2   
 
7.  ADB’s  projects  have  played  critical  role  in  promoting  Indonesia’s  coastal  resource 
management and demonstrating an integrated approach for coastal community development 
and fisheries resource management. The projects have produced a number of impacts and 
benefits, including (i) strengthened capacity and increased awareness of poverty in the coastal 
areas and of the imperatives of sustainable fisheries resource management, among national 
and  regional  government  officials,  the  private  sector,  and  NGOs  and  local  communities 
nationwide; (ii) an improved coastal resource base in the project areas, such as coral reefs, 
mangroves, and coastal fish stocks; and (iii) increased income and improved living conditions of 
poor coastal communities in the project areas. 
 
8.  The lessons learned highlight the (i) importance of the long-term process of coastal 
resource management and poverty reduction; and (ii) need for (a) strong leadership and a 
capable implementation agency; (b) comprehensive analysis and assessment of operational 
requirements, barriers, and risks;  (c) an integrated approach, and well-designed program to 
address  simultaneously  environmental  and  social  issues  in  coastal  areas; 
(d)  active  participation  of  the  private  sector  and  communities  in  project  preparation  and 
implementation;  and  (e)  provision  of  social  and  technical  services  and  tangible  economic 
activities for poor coastal communities. 
 
9.  To implement an effective national ICFRM program, additional efforts and elements 
must be set in place. Action plans need to be developed to link market-based instruments to 
reflect proper fisheries resource pricing. National policy should emphasize the critical roles of 
the regional governments in the ICFRM Project and provide adequate technical and financial 
support.  The  existing  administrative  structure  needs  strengthening  to  implement  national 
policies on the ICFRM Project. A robust ICFRM program should be based on a truly integrated 
approach that simultaneously addresses management of coastal ecosystems, pollution, and 
poverty. To be holistic, an ICFRM program should also deal with the provision of basic social

10.  The magnitude of Indonesia’s problems in the coastal and fisheries sector requires that 
current programs of assistance be continued and expanded to cover a wider geographic area 
following an ecosystem approach to benefit a larger population. The proposed ICFRM Project is 
envisaged to cover nine districts of eight provinces.3 The poverty incidence in the nine districts 
is estimated at 30%, compared to national poverty incidence of 18%. The districts to be covered 
by the feasibility study will be selected using the following criteria: (i) high incidence poverty;  
(ii)  necessity  for  continuation  of  Loan  No.  1570/1571(SF)-INO:  Coastal  Community 
Development and Fisheries Resource Management in the old sites and expansion into new 
areas;  (iii)  importance  of  coastal  resources  and  globally  significant  biodiversity;  and  (iv) 
initiatives and commitment of the regional government, private sector, and communities to 
implement the ICFRM Project. The ICFRM Project will build on the previous coastal fisheries 
resource management initiatives through replication of successful approaches, implementation 
of policies, and effective use of management interventions. The proposed ICFRM Project is in 
line with the Government’s long- and medium-term development objectives as well as ADB’s 
overarching goal of poverty reduction and its medium-term operational strategy, which focuses 
on poverty reduction, natural resource conservation, and environmental protection.  
 
III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
11.  The goal of the ICFRM Project is to support the Government initiatives for poverty 
reduction and sustainable natural resource management in coastal areas.  The TA will assist in 
preparing the ICFRM Project, which will improve the condition of coastal and marine fisheries 
and  related  resources  and  reduce  poverty  in  coastal  communities  by  improving  the 
management  of  coastal  resources  and  ecosystems,  minimizing  threats  to  their  ecological 
integrity, and providing income generation and alternative livelihood opportunities.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will adopt a participatory and consultative approach as a basic strategy to 
involve potential beneficiaries and stakeholders in (i) policy and institutional review and sector 
update; and (ii) detailed technical, economic, financial, social, and environmental studies. The 
TA will examine all risks faced by potential beneficiaries, and ensure compliance with social and 
environmental assessment and safeguards. Relevant information, data, technical approaches, 
policy recommendations, and lessons learned from previous ADB-funded projects and other 
relevant projects will be key inputs in the TA study. The TA will conduct participatory rapid 
appraisals, poverty analysis, and socioeconomic assessment in nine districts of eight provinces 
and organize and conduct stakeholder workshops to discuss on the ICFRM project design and 
implementation arrangements. 
 
13.  The TA will review and update the status of marine and coastal fisheries resources in the 
country,  determine  major  problems,  and  identify  opportunities  and  strategies  to  achieve

1570/1571(SF)-INO: Coastal Community Development and Fisheries Resource Management Project (footnote 2)

and four expansion sites, namely: Pandeglang, Banten; Belu, East Nusa Tenggara; Pantura, Gorontalo; and

4  
sustainable management of fisheries resource. The TA will use surveys, questionnaires, and 
focus group discussions to collect baseline data, and protocols for monitoring and evaluation. 
The  TA  will  engage  in  coalition-building  activities,  such  as  workshops  and  seminars,  to 
engender  project  ownership  and  facilitate  prioritization  of  proposed  interventions  by 
stakeholders.  
 
14.  The  TA  will  formulate  an  investment  project  with  four  components:  (i)  policy  and 
institutional strengthening for national and regional coastal resource management; (ii) coastal 
fisheries resource management, including rehabilitation and protection of fisheries resources 
and related ecosystems through regional governments; (iii) provision of sustainable livelihoods 
assistance4 for income generation for coastal communities and fishers; and (iv) small-scale 
infrastructure development, including fish landing facilities to reduce production losses and 
provide environmental and social investments in pollution control, environmental protection, 
provision of social services, marketing facilities and infrastructure, and population management. 
The project framework will be developed as part of the process to facilitate project design. 
 
15.  The  institutional  assessment  will  include  an  analysis  of  roles,  responsibilities,  and 
capabilities of national and regional agencies, coastal communities, and private sector/NGOs in 
the ICFRM Project. Policy analysis under the TA will include the potential use of market-based 
instruments for paying for resources, and further development of property rights and licensing 
systems. Particular emphasis will be placed in delineating the private sector’s role in project 
design and implementation through appropriate public-private partnership programs. 
 
16.  The TA will assess proposed ICFRM project activities and formulate technical guidelines 
and methods for implementing the activities, taking into consideration technical, environmental, 
and ecological conditions; local initiatives; and the availability of major inputs and support 
facilities.  The  TA  will  identify  economically  viable  and  environmentally  sound  alternative 
livelihood developments for demonstration and replication by community-based organizations 
and the private sector. The output will be a range of options from which people can select and 
design the system that most effectively meets their needs and best fits the opportunities and 
constraints of the local environment. The TA will conduct environmental impact assessments for 
the proposed development activities, identify any positive and negative environmental impacts 
of the investment project, and recommend measures to mitigate possible negative impacts.  
 
17.  The TA will (i) analyze relevant economic information, estimate costs and benefits for the 
proposed ICFRM Project and components, (ii) estimate economic rates of return and financial 
benefits, (iii) conduct economic valuation of environmental impacts and analyze the financial 
viability of the proposed ICFRM project activities, (iv) analyze project risks, (v) review the 
management mechanisms for public funds and recommend suitable financial arrangements in 
accordance with the policy on regional development and decentralization for the subsequent 
ICFRM Project, (vi) assess the financial capacity of participating regional governments, and (vii) 
conduct marketing study for the livelihood products.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1.09 million equivalent, comprising $560,000 in 
foreign exchange cost and $530,000 equivalent in local currency cost. The Government of 
United Kingdom will finance $790,000 equivalent on a grant basis, covering the entire foreign

credit schemes.

5
exchange  cost  of  $560,000  and  $230,000  equivalent  of  the  local  currency  cost.  The 
Government will contribute the balance of the local currency cost of $300,000 equivalent to 
cover local travel, survey, and expenses for the office and counterpart staff. The Government 
has been advised that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The Directorate General of Capture Fisheries (DGCF) of MMAF will be the executing 
agency  (EA)  for  the  TA  and  will  be  responsible  for  overall  TA  administration  and 
implementation. DGCF has extensive experience and capable staff, and implemented ADB-
financed projects well. DGCF’s central office will provide office facilities for the administration of 
TA activities, and other administrative support services. Interagency coordination, monitoring 
and review of TA progress, and guidance to the consultants will be ensured by a steering 
committee  to  be  chaired  by  the  director  general  of  capture  fisheries  and  will  include 
representatives  of  government  agencies  concerned,  such  as  the  National  Development 
Planning Agency (BAPPENAS), Ministry of Finance (MOF), MMAF, DGCF, and other director 
general, of MMAF. 
 
20.  The TA will be implemented over a 6-month period, from January to June 2005, by a 
team of international (20 person-months) and domestic consultants (32 person-months). The 
expertise  will  include  policy  and  institutional  development,  coastal  fisheries  resource 
management, social and community development, microenterprise development, infrastructure 
development,  information  management,  environmental  management,  and  economics  and 
finance. Consultants will be selected by ADB according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants using quality- and cost-based selection. The outline terms of reference of the 
consultants are given in Appendix 3. Simplified technical proposals will be required from short-
listed consulting firms. All procurement under the TA will be done in accordance with ADB's 
Guidelines for Procurement.  
 
21.  DGCF will provide counterpart staff from MMAF and DGCF to work with the team of 
consultants. The counterpart staff will work closely with the team of consultants to formulate and 
evaluate strategies and components for the proposed ICFRM Project and prepare detailed 
assessments  of  selected  strategies  for  ICFRM  project  interventions.  Active  involvement  of 
stakeholders, NGOs, and communities in the design of the proposed ICFRM Project will be 
sought throughout the course of the TA through workshops and focus group discussions, 
midterm and final review missions, and regular communication. A summary initial poverty and 
social analysis is given in Appendix 4. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $790,000 to the Government 
of Indonesia to be financed on a grant basis by the Government of the United Kingdom for 
preparing the Integrated Coastal Fisheries Resource Management Project, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  assist  the  Government  in  preparing  the  Integrated 
Coastal  Fisheries  Resource  Management  (ICFRM)  Project  to  reduce  poverty  among  coastal 
communities  and  reverse  the  degradation  of  coastal fisheries and related  resources and the 
environment. The TA will be implemented by a team of international (about 20 person-months) and 
domestic consultants (about 22 person-months) whose expertise will include policy and institutional 
development,  coastal  fisheries  resource  management,  social  and  community  development, 
microenterprise development, infrastructure development, information management and marketing, 
environmental  management,  and  economics  and  finance.  The  data,  project  concepts,  and 
institutional and policy recommendations from previous projects1 will provide important inputs for 
the TA. 
 
A.  Terms of Reference for Consultants 
1.  Team Leader2 (international, 1 person-month) 
2.  The team leader will (i) prepare the detailed work program and an overall implementation 
schedule for the TA and coordinate the work of the consultant team; (ii) conduct participatory rapid 
appraisals  (PRAs)  in  proposed  sites,  and  conduct  stakeholder’s  workshops,  ensuring  full 
participation of women at all stages throughout TA implementation, and provide inputs in the final 
report to describe the outcomes of PRA and stakeholder workshop activities, (iii) be responsible for 
overall  coordination  of  private  sector,  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  women’s 
organizations, and community participation during the TA implementation; (iv) prepare a project 
framework for ultimate design and implementation of the project benefit monitoring and evaluation 
(BME) system; and (v) prepare TA reports and consolidate the various investment components into 
the proposed ICFRM Project. 
 
2.  Policy and Institutional Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
3.  The specialist will (i) review the Government’s national policy on ICFRM and prepare a time 
frame and program for its implementation; (ii) conduct institutional analysis, evaluate institutional 
capacity and linkages between the main ICFRM-mandated agencies, assess roles, responsibilities 
and capabilities of local agencies, coastal communities and private sector, women’s organizations 
and NGOs in ICFRM, and evaluate past and ongoing efforts of the Government in the institutional 
capacity-building  toward  ICFRM;  (iii)  design  the  capacity-building  programs  to  enhance  the 
national coordination and management system, research network, and information systems for 
ICFRM; (iv) recommend an institutional arrangement for implementing ICFRM activities; and (v) 
formulate a BME system. The analysis of participation of private sector in the project design and 
implementation will be emphasized.

among the components and activities, and enumerate the nonquantifiable effects of the Project 
that may influence project design and investment decisions; (iv) conduct market and financial 
analyses for the proposed microenterprise and livelihood programs; (v) prepare guidelines and 
criteria  for  economic  evaluation  and  develop  a  method  for  market  analysis,  (vi)  analyze  the 
potential uses of market-based instruments such as rent for coastal resource use, and taxes and 
fees  for  ICFRM  activities;  (vii)  review  credit  and  social  fund  programs  extended  to  coastal 
communities, and assess the effectiveness of these program; and (viii) recommend operational 
and contractual arrangements among the participating groups, review the mechanisms of public 
funds  flow,  and  design  a  financial  arrangement  in  accordance  with  the  policy  on  regional 
development and decentralization for the Project.  
 
4.  Coastal Resources Management Specialist (international, 4 person-months) 
5.  The specialist will (i) review of policies, programs, and institutional arrangements for coastal 
fisheries  and  related  marine  habitat  conservation;  (ii)  using  available  coastal  resources  and 
environmental information in the country, prepare a resources and environmental profile for each 
proposed site; (ii) identify the major causes and factors affecting the resources and habitats, and 
recommend  a  range  of  solutions  for  causes  of  negative  factors  and  propose  appropriate 
management measures for coastal fisheries resource protection; (iii) review resource assessment, 
ICFRM,  and  the  environmental  management  program  and  assess  their  effectiveness  and 
corresponding impacts; (iv) prepare site selection criteria and technical guidelines considering such 
factors  as  environmental  and  resource  conditions,  local  initiatives,  socioeconomic  conditions, 
institutional  receptivity  and  preparedness,  and  compatibility  with  local  development  plans;  (v) 
prepare the terms of references, procedures, and guidelines for study activities to be used in 
implementing the ICFRM Project such as resource assessments, and evaluate their relevance and 
applicability to the Project; (vi) design a coastal fisheries resource management component that 
will include a method for preparing coastal fisheries resource plans and zoning systems; and (vii) 
assess the effectiveness of the management of established marine protected areas. 
 
5.  Coastal Environmental Engineer (international, 3 person-months) 
6.  The  specialist  will  (i)  review  coastal  resources  data  and  technical  information  in  the 
proposed sites for coastal pollution and erosion control activities, assess the technical viability of 
investment activities, and review the selection criteria for investment activities;  (ii) prepare detailed 
technical criteria for site selection considering technical viability, availability of natural resources, 
environmental conditions, and support for improved living and environmental conditions of coastal 
communities; (iii) help (a) determine the assumptions for analyzing the economic and financial 
viability of identified infrastructure and facilities for coastal environmental protection; and (b) estimate 
the  total  investment  costs  for  the  coastal  environmental  protection;  and  (iv)  prepare  the 
implementation arrangements for the coastal environmental protection activities.

12  Appendix 3 
6.  Coastal Fisheries Infrastructure Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
7.  The specialist will (i) work closely with coastal resources management specialist to collect, 
compile, and review fisheries resources data, fisheries information (fishing efforts), and technical 
information at the proposed sites of small-scale fisheries infrastructure and landing facilities; (ii) 
assess the technical viability of these activities; (iii) prepare detailed technical criteria for site 
selection for fisheries infrastructure and landing facilities considering technical viability, availability 
of  fish  resources,  optimum  use    of  infrastructure  facilities,  environmental  conservation  and 
improvement, and support to small-scale coastal fishing communities; (iv) assist the resource 
economist in determining the assumptions for analyzing the economic and financial viability of 
selected  fisheries infrastructure and landing facilities and estimating the total investment costs for 
the  small-scale  fisheries  infrastructure  improvement  activities;  and    (v)  assist  the  institutional 
specialist  in  preparing  the  implementation  arrangements  for  coastal  fisheries  infrastructure 
development and recommend improvements on the implementation arrangement to include the 
participation of the private sector and coastal communities. 
 
7.  Social Development Specialist (international, 2 person-months) 
8.  The specialist will (i) provide guidance in the identification of target beneficiaries and other 
stakeholders, as well as the type of information to be generated to facilitate poverty analysis and 
description of the socioeconomic status of communities in the Project sites; (ii) determine the 
specific items to be covered by the socioeconomic survey to be conducted under the TA; (iii) take 
the lead in the consolidation, summary, and analysis of the survey data; (iv) lead social dimensions 
analysis, including poverty impact analysis and distribution of Project benefits among the target 
population  and  targeted  poor,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for  Social  Analysis  of 
Development  Projects,  Handbook  of  Poverty  Impact  Analysis  of  Projects,  and  Handbook  for 
Incorporating Poverty Impact in Economic Analysis of Projects; and (v) assess the likelihood of 
social conflicts that could arise from potential project interventions, e.g., impacts on indigenous 
communities and involuntary resettlement issues (a) asset or livelihood losses, and (b) restrictions 
on access to coastal resources; suggest mechanisms to ameliorate these impacts and issues; and 
prepare appropriate indigenous peoples development plan and resettlement plan, if required. 
 
8.  Policy and Institutional Specialist (domestic, 3 person-months) 
9.  The specialist will assist the international policy specialist to (i) review the Government’s 
relevant national and regional policy on ICFRM and prepare a program for the implementation of a 
national  ICFRM  policy;  (ii)  conduct  institutional  analysis;  evaluate  institutional  capacity  and 
linkages  between  the  main  ICFRM-mandated  agencies,  assess  roles,  responsibilities,  and 
capabilities of local agencies, coastal communities, the private sector, women’s organizations, and 
NGOs in ICFRM; and evaluate Government efforts in the policy development and institutional 
capacity-building towards ICFRM; (iii) design the capacity building programs to enhance national 
coordination and management systems, research networks, and information systems for ICFRM; 
and (v) formulate a project BME system based on the project framework analysis. 
 
9.  Community Development Specialist and Sociologist (domestic, 5 person-
months) 
10.  The specialist will (i) use rapid appraisal methodologies and available socioeconomic data 
to prepare a socioeconomic and gender-specific profile of the target population; (ii) supervise the 
conduct of a household survey to obtain feedback from potential beneficiaries to collect and 
analyze pertinent statistics and qualitative information to prepare a poverty analysis and provide a 
basis for recommending project-level resource protection and poverty interventions consistent with

Appendix 3  13 
the objectives of ADB ‘s poverty reduction strategies and the ADB-Indonesia poverty partnership 
agreement; (iii) examine income and consumption patterns and/or accessible human development 
indicators of target communities; and (iv) recommend a poverty intervention approach, including 
appropriate implementation arrangements for the coastal community development program.  
    
10.  Coastal Environmental Specialist (domestic, 5 person-months) 
11.  The  specialist  will  (i)  review  environmental  data  in  the  proposed  coastal  resources 
management and pollution control sites and assess their possible environmental impacts, and 
conduct a comprehensive environmental assessment consistent with Government regulations and 
guidelines and ADB’s Environment Policy 2002 and Environmental Assessment Guidelines 2003, 
covering: (a) initial screening of proposed project areas to determine if they cover areas that are 
ecologically sensitive or are intended as nature reserves; (b) initial environmental examination of 
proposed  project  activities  and  recommend  measures  to  avoid  negative  impacts;  and  (c) 
recommend,  if  environmental  issues  are  identified  during  the  project  preparation,  additional 
environmental  studies  and  recategorization  of  the  Project  and  the  preparation  of  a  full 
environmental impact assessment report; (ii) review national and regional government policies on 
natural  resources  and  environmental  conservation  in  the  proposed  project  sites  and  identify 
potential conflicts between project plans and policies on the use of natural resources and pollution 
control; (iii) recommend the marine environmental education program; and (iv) prepare an overall 
assessment of potential positive or negative environmental impact of the project components, 
using  ADB’s  environment  policy,  Operations  Manual,  and  guidelines.  Include  the  critical 
parameters for overall project environmental review, for selected agriculture and natural resources 
development projects. Recommend measures to avoid any negative impacts identified.  
   
11.  Marine Ecologist (domestic, 5 person-months) 
12.  The specialist will (i) review the status of major marine habitats, identify major marine 
endangered  species  in  proposed  project  areas,  recommend  a  range  of  optional  solutions  to 
problems, and propose appropriate conservation measures to protect the major marine habitats 
and endangered species, and review the current status of research programs on marine habitats 
and endangered species, and propose appropriate techniques to strengthen these researches; and 
(ii) assist in the preparation of coastal fisheries resource management and biodiversity conservation 
activities. 
 
12.  Microenterprise Specialist (domestic, 4 person-months)  
13.  The specialist will (i) review the economic and income generation activities of cooperatives 
and  people’s  organizations  in  the  proposed  sites  and  assess  their  abilities  in  implementing 
economic development projects and financial management, and recommend alternative livelihood 
opportunities microenterprise development activities for coastal poor and local communities; (ii) 
identify  the  needs  for  and  current  technical  extension  service  programs  for  supporting 
microenterprise development for coastal communities and cooperatives, and recommend improved 
technical extension programs applicable for microenterprise development in project areas; and (iii) 
identify the current sources of credit and social funds for coastal communities and cooperatives 
and  assess  the  effectiveness  of  these  credit  programs,  and  recommend  improved  financing 
schemes for microenterprise development.

14  Appendix 3 
13.  Small-Scale Fisheries Infrastructure and Landing Facilities Specialist 
(domestic, 4 person-months) 
14.  The specialist will (i) work closely with other consultants to collect, compile, and review 
fisheries resources data, fishing efforts and landing information, and technical information at the 
proposed sites of small-scale fisheries infrastructure and landing facilities, and assess the technical 
viability of these proposed fisheries infrastructure activities; (ii) with the international fisheries 
infrastructure  specialist,  prepare  detailed  technical  criteria  for  site  selection  for  fisheries 
infrastructure and landing facilities, considering technical viability, availability of fish resources, 
optimum  use  of  infrastructure  facilities,  cost  recovery,  environmental  conservation  and 
improvement,  and  support  to  coastal  fishing  communities;  and  (iii)  help  in  preparing  the 
implementation arrangements and cost estimates for coastal fisheries infrastructure activities. 
 
14.  Gender Specialist (domestic, 3 person-months) 
15.  The  specialist  will  (i)  analyze  socioeconomic  data  on  women's  participation  in  coastal 
resources  conservation  and  community  development  among  coastal  fishing  communities;  (ii) 
conduct gender analysis, and review women's participation in alternative livelihood projects and 
women's access to and availability of socially necessary infrastructure and services; (iii) assess the 
role  of  women  in  coastal  community  organizations  and  coastal  resources  management  and 
analyze likely positive and negative impacts of project interventions on women; and (iv) help 
conduct the PRA and organize the stakeholder workshops; prepare the gender-based guidelines, 
procedures, terms of reference, and gender criteria for the selection of NGOs and programs; and 
formulate a BME system, integrating gender analysis at all stages of the project implementation. 
 
15.  Marketing Information Specialist (domestic, 3 person-months) 
16.  The specialist will (i) conduct market surveys and identify market opportunities, both local 
and international, for livelihood products and fish and aquatic species covered by selected project 
interventions;  (ii)  review  the  key  international  and  national  regulations  and  summarize  these 
international and local regulations governing the marketing of fish and fish products; (iii) identify the 
key post-harvest issues and marketing problems that constrain the diversification of markets or 
product development for livelihood products, fish, and other aquatic species covered by selected 
project interventions, and develop project interventions to overcome the constraints for project 
products; (iv) prepare a program to assist the Directorate General of Capture Fisheries to establish 
a sustainable market information system that can effectively distribute the market information to 
coastal communities and capture fish producers, particularly for the small-scale fishers; and (v) 
recommend the program to improve the marketing information system and marketing system for 
products of small-scale fishers.  
 
B.  Reports 
17.  The consultants will prepare the following reports for submission to the Government and 
ADB: (i) an inception report, to be submitted at the end of the first month; (ii) a draft final report, by 
the end of the seventh month, and to be followed by a tripartite meeting to review the draft final 
report; and (iii) the final report, by the end of the eighth month after incorporating the views and 
comments made by the Government and ADB during the tripartite meeting.

SUMMARY INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 
       
Is the sector identified as a national    Yes  Is the sector identified as a national   Yes 
priority in country poverty analysis?      priority in country poverty partnership   
      No  agreement?      No 
Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Indonesia: 
 
About 36 million people are estimated to live below the poverty line in Indonesia, of whom 75% live in rural 
areas (2000). Poverty is widespread in the coastal villages, with coastal households composed mostly of 
small fishers, fish processors, and workers in the fishing industry and allied fields. Most of the coastal 
villagers are highly dependent on fishing for their livelihood, with many claiming that their income from fishing 
is not sufficient to meet even their basic subsistence needs. They have limited capacity to explore new fishing 
grounds or other opportunities for increasing fish catch and income, have limited facilities to store fishery 
products, lack marketing channels, and have limited transportation services. Human development is weak; 
coastal residents have limited education and limited access to health and other basic social services such as 
potable water supply, sewerage and sanitation, electricity, and transportation. The goal of the Integrated 
Coastal Fisheries Resource Management (ICFRM) Project is to reduce poverty among coastal communities, 
improve the management and condition of coastal and marine fisheries resources, protect the coastal and 
marine  environment,  and  facilitate  the  participation  of  the  private  sector,  nongovernment  organizations 
(NGOs), and coastal communities in ICFRM and social development activities. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Proposed Poverty  
    Classification 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?    
   
The project preparatory technical assistance (TA) will assess the requirements of the 
coastal communities and other beneficiaries for financial and technical assistance in 
ICFRM interventions, particularly in microenterprise and social infrastructure development, 
and analyze the feasibility of proposed strategies and activities in poverty reduction. The 
TA will ensure that the project framework will allow for interventions and monitoring 
mechanisms to improve human development, including income, nutrition, and general 
social welfare. A poverty analysis will be undertaken to estimate the expected impact of 
the Project on poor coastal communities, other stakeholders (including NGOs, community 
organizations, and other local groups), and government agencies, particularly regional 
and district governments. The analysis will include an evaluation of distribution of project 
benefits and impacts across income groups and estimate the distribution of project effects 
on the poor, as outlined in the Asian Development Bank’s Handbook for Integrating 
Poverty Impact Assessment in the Economic Analysis of Projects. 
 
C.  Participation Process 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
 
During the review of ongoing and completed projects, the consultants will identify and consult with all 
stakeholders and determine the roles and functions of the target groups. In particular, the consultants will 
undertake a participatory rapid appraisal (PRA) or similar approaches to gather background information on 
the study communities, meet with key individuals and local groups, and engage them in dialogue to identify 
development needs and constraints. The outcome of the analysis will form the basis for proposing selection 
criteria and specific mechanisms for the inclusion of communities and the identification of target groups under 
the proposed Project. 
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
 
The TA will be implemented in a fully participatory manner. The consultants will organize and conduct a

16  Appendix 4 
series of stakeholder workshops at the national level and focus group discussions at each selected Project 
site during TA implementation to solicit stakeholder inputs in the assessment of the current situation and the 
design of Project strategies and specific activities for incorporation in the proposed Project. 
 
D.  Gender Development 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
Gender-disaggregated data will be collected during the baseline surveys to be conducted under the TA. The 
potential role of women in ICFRM and microenterprise development will be given focus, especially their 
potential role in small business development and management, strengthening of existing or creation of new 
cooperatives, and coastal and fisheries resource management initiatives. The TA will ensure that women are 
provided with equal opportunities in training and microenterprise development, especially in the area of fish 
processing and marketing and other livelihood activities. 
 
Has an output been prepared?      Yes     No 
 
A gender plan will be prepared by the consultants as part of project design. The gender plan will be based on 
a prior assessment of gender issues in the selected project sites and include specific interventions and 
activities aimed at addressing identified gender issues.
